div.p:
Of true faith, fromwhence it commeth, that it is an
aslured beleefe of the minde, whose onely stay
is upon God and his word
N my last sermon
I declared unto
you, how that the
perfect exposition of
Gods worde doth
differ nothing from
AdocFbye rule of true faith,
and the love of God and our neigh
bour. For undoubtedly, that sense of
Scripture is corrupted, which doth
square from faith, and the two poynts
of charitie. I have nowe therefore next
to treat of true faith and charitie to
wards God and our neighbour, to the
intent that no man may finde lacke of
any thing heerein.
And first therefore by Gods helpe, and
the good meanes of your prayers, I wil
speake of true faith,
This word Faith or beleefe, is di
versly used in the common talk of me
For it is taken for any kinde of Reli
gion or honour done to God. As we say
the Christian faith, the lewish faith,
and the Furkish faith. Faith or beleefe
also, is taken for a conceived opinion of
any thing that is told us, as when we
heare any thing rehearsed unto us out
of the Indian or Ethiopian hystorie,
we by and by say that wee beleeve it,
and yet notwithstanding wee put no
confidence in it nor hope to have any
commoditie thereby at all. This is that
faith, wherewith saint James sayeth
that the Devil beleeveth ec trembleth.
Last of all, faith is commonly put for
an allured and undoubted confidence
in God and his word. Among the He
brues faith taketh her name of truth,
certeintie and allured constancie. The
Latines call that faith, when that is,
done which is said. Whereuppon one
saith, I demaunde of thee whether
thou beleevest or no? Thou aunswe
rest, I beleeve: Doe then that which
thou saiest, and it is faith. Therefore in :
this treatise of ours, Faith is an un
doubted beleefe, most firmely groun
ded in the minde. This faith, which is
a settled and undoubted perswasion or
beleefe leaning upon God & his word,
is diversly defined by ye perfecter Di
vines. S. Paul saith, Faith is the sub
stance of thinges hoped for, the evi
dence of thinges not seene. The sub
stance or hypostasis is the foundation.
or the unmoveable prop, which uphol
deth us, & wheron we leane & lye with
out peril or danger. The things hoped
for, are thinges celestiall, eternall, and
inuisible. And therefore Paul sayeth.
Faith is an unmoveable foundation,
and a most allured confidence of gods
promises, that is, of life everlasting and
all his good benefits. Moreover Paul
himelfe, making an erposition of that
which he had spoken, immediately af,
ter, saith: Faith is the argument of
thinges not seene. An argument or
proofe is an evident demoustration,
wherby we manifestly prove ye, which
otherwise should he doubtful, so that in
him whom we undertooke to instruct,
there may remaine no doubt at all,
But now touthing ye mysteries of god
revealed in Gods word, in theselves
or in their owne nature they can not
be seene with bodilie eyes : and there
fore are called thinges not seene. But,
this faith by giving light to the minde,
dooth in heart perceive them, even as
they are set foorth in the word of God.
Faith therefore according to the de
sinition of Paul, is in the minde a most
evident saying, and in the heart a most
certaine perceiving of thinges inuisi
ble, that is, of thinges eternall, of God
I say and all those thinges which hee
in his word setteth forth unto us con
cerning spirituall thinges. To this de
finition of Paules they had an eye,
which defined Faith in this forte.
Faith is a grounded persuasion of hea
venly thinges, in the meditation wher
of wee ought so to oecupie our selves
for the allured truthes sake of Gods
worde, thatwe may beleeve that in
minde we doe see those things as well
as with our eyes we do behold things
sensibly perceived, Zc easie to be seene,
This description doth not greatly dif
fer from this definition of an other
godly & learned man who saith: Faith
is a fledfast perswasion of the minde,
whereby we doe fully decree with our
selves that gods truth is so sure, that
he can neither will nor choose but
performe that which he in his worde
hath promised to fulsill. Againe, Faith
is a stedfast allurednesse of conscience,
which dooth imbrace Christ in the
same fort, wherein he is offered unto
us by the Gospell. Another there is
which after the same manner almost
defineth faith in this forte: Faith is a
gift inspired by God into the mind of
man, wherby without any doubting at
all he doth beleeve that to bee most
true what so ever God hath either
taught or promised in the bookes of
both the Testaments. The very same
author of this definition therfore doth
ertend faith to three termes of time, to
the time past, the time present, and the
time to come: For he teacheth to be
lieve that the world was made by god,
and whatsoever the holy Scriptures
doe declare to have beene done in the
olde world: also that Christ dying for
us, is the only salvation of them which I
believe: and that by the same God at
this day also, the world and Church
are governed or preserved, aud that in
Christ the faithfull are saved : last of
all, that that shall most alluredly light
upon the ungodly and ye godly, whatso
ever the holy Scriptures doe either
threaten or promise,
Out of all these definitions therfore
being diligently considered, wee maye
according to ye Scriptures make this
description of faith. Faith is a gift of
God, powred into man from heaven,
whereby he is taught with an undou
ted perswasion, wholie to leane to
God and his worde, in which worde
God doth freely promise life and all
good thinges in Christ, and wherein
all truth necessarie to be beleeved, is
plainly declared. Which description
of faith, I will by Gods helpe in this
that followeth unfolde into parts, and
by assertion of places out of the Scrip
tures, will both confirme and make
manifest unto you, Pee, as hitherto
ye have done, so stil give diligent eare,
and in your heartes pray earnestly to
God.
Frst of al, the cause or beginning of
faith commeth not of any man, or any
strength of man, but of God himelfe,
who by his holy spirite, inspireth faith
into our heartes. For in the Gospell
the Lord saith, No man commeth to
me, unlesse my father draw him
And againe, Fleshe and bloude
ssaith the Lord to Peter, confessinge
Christ in true faith) hath not revealed
this to thee, but my father which is
in heaven. Whereunto the Apostle
Paul alludeth when he sayth, we are
not able of our selves to thinke any
thing as of our selves, but all our abili
tie is of God. And in an other place, To
you it is given for Chrisl, not onely to
beleeve in him, but also to suffer for
his sake. Faith therefore is powred in
to our hearts by God, who is the wel
spring and cause of all goodnesse,
And yet we have to consider heere,
that God in giving & inspiring faith,
dooth not use his absolute polver, or
miracles in working, but a certaine
ordinarie meanes agreeable to mans
capacitie: although he can in deede give
faith without those meanes, to whom,
when, and how it pleaseth him? But
we read, that the Lord hath used this
ordinarie meanes, even from the first
creation of all things. Whom he mea
neth to bestowe knowledge and fayth
on: to them he sendeth teachers, by the
word of God to preach true faith unto
them. Not because it lieth in mans
polver, wil, or ministerie, to give faith,
nor because the outward word spoken
by mans mouth, is able of it selfe to
bring faith: but the voyce of man, and
the preaching of Gods word, doo teach
us what true faith is, or what God
dooth wil and commaund us to believe.
For God himselfe alone by sending his
holy spirite into the hearts and minds
of men, dooth open our heartes, per
swade our mindes, and cause us with
all our heart to believe that, which we
by his word and teaching have learned
to believe.
The Lord coulde by miracle from
heaven, without any preaching at all,
have bestowed faith in Christ upon
Cornelius the Centurion at Cesaria:
but yet by an Angel he dooth send him
to the preaching of Peter. And while.
Peter preacheth, God by his holy spis
rite worketh in the heart of Corneli
us, causing him to believe his prea
thing. Verily S. Paule saith, Now
shall they beleeve in him of whome
they have not heard: Now shall they
heare without a preacher: And howe
shall they preach if they bee not sent:
So then, faith commeth by hearing, E
hearing by the word of God. In ano
ther place also. who is Paule saith he,
or what is Apollos, but Ministers, by,
whom ye have beleeved, according as
God hath given to everie one) I have,
planted, Apollos watered, but God
hath given increase. So then hee that
lanteth is nothing, nor hee that wa
treth, but God that giveth increase,
With this doctrine of saint Peter and
Saint Paule dooth that agree which
Augustine writeth in the Preface of
his booke of Christian doctrine, where
hee sayth: That which wee have to
learne at nsans hande, let everie one
learne at mans hand without disdaine,
And let us not goe about to tempt
him in whome wee beleeve, neither
being deceived let us thinke scorne
to goe to Churth, to heare or learne
out of bookes, looking still when we
shall bee rapt up into the third hea
ven.
Let us take heede of such like temp
tatios of pride, and let us rather have
this in our mindes, that even the Apo
stle Paule himelfe, although hee were
cast prostrate, & instructed by the cal
ling of God from heaven, was never
thelesse sent to a man to be taught the
will of God : and that Cornelius, al
though god had heard his praiers, was
comitted to Peter to be instructed, by
whome he should not onely receive the
Sacraments: but should also heare
what he ought to believe, what to hope
for and what to love: all which things
notwithstanding might have been done
by the Angell, tc. The same Augu
stine also in his Epistle to the Circen
ses saith: Even he worketh conversi
on and bringeth it to passe, who by
his ministers doth warne us outward
ly with the signes of thinges, but in
wardly doth by himelfe teach us with
the verie thinges theselves. Also in his
treatise upon the 26. of Iohn: what
doe men (saith he) when they preach
outwardly: what doe I nowe while I
speake) I drive into your eares a noise
of wordes: but unlesse he which is with
in doe reveale it, what say l, or what
speake Iy he that is without doth hus
bande the tree, but hee within is the
creator of it. ete. This said he,
But, even as the Lorde his desire is,
to have us believe his worde, dfor the
Prophet cryeth out and saith: To day
if yee will heare his voice, harden not
your harts: ) So in like maner, he doth
require of us al which heare his word,
that we be not slacke in praying. For
in hearing the worde of God, we must
pray for the gift of faith, that the Lord
may open our harts, covert our soules,
breake and beate downe the hardnesse
of our mindes, and increase the mea
sure of faith bestowed uppon us. Of
this order of prayer, there are many
examples in the holy scriptures. Whe
the Lorde in the Gospell sayde to one,
Canst thou beleeve) to him that belee
veth all thinges are possible: He made
answere saying: I beleeve Lord, helpe
thon mine unbeliefe. The Apostles
also cry to the Lord and say: O Lorde
increase our faith. Moreover, this
prayer, wherin we desire to have faith
powred into us, is of the grace and gift
of GOD, and not of our owne righte
ousnesse, which before God is none at
all. This therefore is lefte unto us,
for a thing most certaine and undoub
tedly true, that true faith is the meere
gift of God, which is by the holy ghost
from heaven, bestowed uppon our
mindes, and is declared unto us in the
worde of trueth, by teachers sent of
God, and is obtained by earnest prai
ers which cannot be tyred. Whereby
we learne that wee ought often and
attentively to heare the word of God,
and never cease to pray to God for the
obtaining of true faith,
But that this faith inspired from
heaven, and learned out of the worde
of trueth, doeth put into mans minde
an undoubted perswasion, that is, that
whatsoever we believe in the worde
of God, we doe believe it most allured
ly without wavering or doubting, be
ing altogether as sure to have the
thing, as faith doth believe to have it
for I use this worde perswasion, not
as it is comonly taken, but for a firme
assent of minde inspired and perswa
ded by the holy ghost) that this faith a
saye, doth put into mans minde this
undoubted perswasion, I meane to de
clare by the example of Abrahams
faith, which Paule in the fourth chap
ter to the Romanes describeth in these
wordes. Abraham contrarie to hope
beleeved in hope: and he fainted not
in faith, neyther considered hee his
owne body now dead, when he was al
most an hundred yeares olde, nor the
deadnesse of saraes wombe, he stac
kered not at the promise of God tho
rowe unbeliefe, but became strong in
faith and gave the glorie to God, ha
vinge a sure perswasion that hee
which had promised, was able also to
performe. In these wordes of the
Apostle, there are certaine notes to
be obserued, which do prove to us that
Faith doth bring an allured perswa
deth not to tentation, neither is drow
ned nor sticketh in the mire of stacke
ring, but laying hold upon the promised
worde of truth, getteth up againe by
strugling, and is confirmed. So wee
reade, that at the promise of God, this
came into Abrahams minde. What,
shall there a Sonne bee borne to thee
that art an hunored yeares olde: This
was that infirmitie, and stackering or
weaknes of faith. But here thr Apostle
commending Abrahams faith, which
overcame and yeelded not, teaching us
also of what fort true faith ought to be,
that is, a firme and most allured per
swasion, saith: Abraham fainted not
in faith, neither considered his owne
bodie dead, when hee was almost an
hundred yeares olde, nor the dead
nesse of saraes wombe. Loe, this
thought came into Abrahams minde.
Shal a sonne be borne to mee that am
an hunored yeares old: But he fainted
not in faith. The faith of Abraham be
gan not to droope by reason of this tep
tation.
For, he considered not the weaknes
that was in himself, nothing answera
ble to the promise of God. What then
He stackered not at the promise of God
through unbeliefe. That is, he gave no
place to unbeliefe to be tempted of it:
he fell not to his owne reasons and
doubtfull inquisitions, as unbelievers
are wont to doe For Gods promise
being once set before the eyes of his
mind, so that I say he stucke unmove
ably, casting off all doubts and reasons
of his owne. For, faith hath no re
spect at all to the weakenesse, mise
rie, or lacke which is properly in man
kinde, but setteth her whole staye in
the polver of God. So then, I saye,
Abraham was strong in faith, that
is, he prevayled and gotte the upper
hande in his temptation. For, this
sion into the minde and heart of man
and so, that Faith is an undoubted co
fidence of things beleeved, whereto the
heart is made privie, that is, that true
Faith doeth not flye too and fro from
place to place in the heart of man, but
that beeing deepely rooted in Christ, it
sticketh in the hart which is enlighte
ned.
First, saieth the Apostle, Abraham
contrarie to hope, beleeved in hope:
that is to say, there he had a constant
hope, where notwithstanding hee had
nothing to hope after, if all things had
beene weighed according to the maner
of this worlde. But Hope is a most
firm and undoubted looking after those
thinges which we believe: So that we
see that the Apostle did make faith ma
nifest by hope, and by the certaine
tie of hope, did declare the allured con
stancie of faith. After that saith he,
Abraham fainted not in faith, nor
stackered at the promise of God tho
rouoh unbeliefe, but was stronge in
faith.
Ther are two kinds of ftackerings
in mankinde: The one is that which
being overcome by evill temptations,
doth bende to desperation, and the de
spising of Gods promises. Such was
the stackering of those ten spies of the
holy lande, of whom mention is made
in the thirteen and fourteene chapter of
Numbers.
The other stackering, is rather to be
called a weak infirmity of faith, which
also is tempted it selfe : that nowe I
may not make rehearsall to you, how
that in us all by the spot of originall
sin, is naturally grafted a certain kind
of unbeliefe, and that mans minde is
at no time so inlightened or confir
med, but that cloudie mystes of igno
raunce and doubtinges doe sometimes
arise: yet notwithstanding, faith yeel
is an argument to shewe that hee had
the upper hande: He fainted not, nor
wated meake in faith. It followeth
in the Apostle, Abraham gave GO)
the glorie, to witte, in beleeving that
GOD wisheth well to mankinde
and that hee is a true God and almigh
tie.
For he giveth God his glory, which
attributeth to God the properties of
God, & doth not gainsay the word and
promise of God. For John the Apostle
saith: Te that beleeveth not in God,
maketh God a lyar, Abraham there
fore beleeved in God, and in belee
ving gave God the glorie. The Apo
stle Paul goeth forwarde and saieth,
Hee was throughly perswaded, or cer
tified, that hee which had promised
was alble also to performe, Paul u
sed the Ereeke woorde mwe durnseie,
which is all one as if you should saye,
beeing certified. For, wwerderis doeth
signifie fully to certifie : whereupon
Thnes tris is an allured faith given un
to us which is made by waye of ar
gnment, or by the thing it selfe. And
they call that :wnreemus, which we call
a certification, as when a thing by
perswasiss is so beate into our minds,
that after that we never doubt anye
more.,
Therefore faith did certifie Abraham,
and with undoubted perswasions did
bring him to the point never to doubt,
but that GODwas able to performe
what he had promised, in faith therfore
he stuck unmoveable to the promise of
God, being alluredly certified that hee
should obtaine whatsoever God had
promised.
It is certaine therefore and plain
ly declared by the woordes of hte Apo
stle, that true Fayth is an undoubted
perswasion in the minde of the belee
ver : even so to have the thing as his
beleefe is, and as he is saide to have it
in the expresse worde of God. There
by also we learne, that faith is not the
unstable and unaduised confidence of
him which believeth every greate and
unpossible thing. For, faith is ruled &
bound to the word of God, to the word
of God, I say, rightly and truly under
stoode,
The godly and faithfull therefore,
doe not by and by, out of the omnipo
tencie of God, gather what they list,
as though God therfore would do eve
ry thing beeause he ean do all thinges,
or that faith should therefore believe
every thing, because it is written: All
thinges are possible to him that belee
veth. For, his faith is therefore a
greate deale more, because that which
hee doth beleeve, is so set downe and
declared in the word of God, as he do
eth believe.
Furthermore, where the Lorde in
the Gospel saith. All thinges are pos
sible to him that beleeveth, wee must
not take that saying to bee absolutely
spoken, but to be ioyned to the worde,
will, and glory of God, & the safetie of
our soules. For, all thinges which
GOD in his worde hath promised)
all thinges whiche GOD. will
have, and lastly, all thinges which I
make to the glorie of God, & the fafe
garde of our soules, are possible to him
that beleeveth. And for that cause,
the Apostle both openly and plainely
saide: whatsoever God hath promi
sed, that same hee is, able also to
performe. For whatsoever he hath not
promised, &: whatsoever pleaseth not
his divine maiesty, or is contrarie to
the will and expresse worde of God,
that cannot GOD doe, not because
hee can not, but because he will not.
God could make bread of stones, but
wee must not therefore believe that
stones are bread, neyther are they
bread therefore, because God can doe
all thinges. This yee shall understand
better and more fully, whereas a litle
hereafter I shall shew unto you, that
true faith strayeth not nor wavereth
wandring too and fro, but cleaveth
close and sticketh fast to God and his
worde,
In the meane season because wee
have shewed out of Paules wordes by
the example af Abraham, that faith is
a substance and undoubted perswasi
on in the hearte. And because many
doe stifly stande in it, that man is not
surely certeine of his salvation, I will
adde a fewe examples out of the Go
spell, whereby they may plainely per
ceive that faith is a more sure ground,
and setled opinion touthing God and
our salvation. And sirst verily the
Centurion, of whom mention is made
in the Gospel, had conceived a stedfast
hope that his seruant should be healed
of the Lorde. For he understoode howe
greate and mightie thinges hee promi
sed to them that believe. Hee gathered
also by the woorkes of Christ, that it
was an easie matter for him to restore
his seruant to health againe. There
fore hee commeth to the Lorde, and a
mong other talke sayeth. It is no rea
Ion that thou shouldest come under
my roofe, yea doe but saie the worde
and my seruaunt shall be made whole.
These wordes doe testifie, that in the
hearte and minde of the Centurion,
there was a sure perswasion of most
alssured health, which by a certeyne
comparison, hee doeth make manifest
and more fully expresse. For I my
selfe am a man under the authoritie of
an other, and undermee I have soul
diours, and Isay to one, goe, and he
goeth: and to an other, eome, and hee
commeth: and to my seruant doe this,
and he doeth it. Then the Lorde per
ceived this certificatio of his mind, by
his words most full of faith, he crieth
out, that in al Israel he hath not found
so great faith,
The same again in the Gospel, spea
keth notably of ye womas faith which
was sorely plagved with the bloudye
flure. And that faith was an undoub
ted perswasion in her hearte once illu
minated, we may thereby understand,
because she (being first in deede stirred
up by the works & words of the Lord)
thought thus within her selfe, if Idoe
but touch his garment, I shalbe whole.
And therforepressing through the thic
kest of the throng, cometh to the Lord,
But why heape I together many ex
amples: doth not the onely faith of the
Chananitish or Syrophenissian wo
man, declare more plainly than that it
can be denied, how that faith is a most
allured perswasion of things believed:
For being over passed, and as it were
contemned of the Lord, shee wavereth
not in faith, but following him, & hea
ring also that the Lord was sent to the
lost sheepe of the house of Israel, shee
goeth on to woorship him. Moreover,
being put backe, & as it were touched
with the foule reproch of a dogge, shee
goeth forwarde yet humbly to cast her
selfe prostrate before the Lorde, reque
sting to obtaine the thing that she desi
red. She would not have persevered so
stiffely if faith had not beene a certifi
cation in her beleving mind and heart,
Wherefore, the Lord moved with that
faith of hirs, cryed: woman, great is
thy faith, bee it done to thee even as
thou wilt.
It is manifest therefore, by all these
testimonies of the holy Scripture, that
faith is a stedfast & undouted persuasio
in the minde and heart of the believer,
This, being now brought to an end,
let us see what it is whereupon mans
faith doth leane, and also how we may
clearely perceive, that faith is not a
vayne and unstalbe opinion cas a litle
before wee were about to saye) of any
thinge whatsoever conceived in the
minde of man, but that it is tyed by
and contayned within bounds, and as
it were certaine conditions. In the
definition therefore of faith, we sayde
that faith bendeth to Godwarde, and
leaneth on his worde. God therefore
and the worde of God, is the obiect
2.
or foundation of true faith. The thing
whereon a man may leane safely, sure
ly, and without all manner doubting,
must needes be stedfast and altogether
unmoveable, which doeth give health,
which doth preserue, and which doth sil
up or minister all fulnes unto us.
For this doth faith seeke and request,
But this is not else where tha in God.
On God, alone therefore doeth true
faith bende and leane. God is everla
sting, chifely good, wise, iust, mightie
and true of worde. And that doeth he
testifie by his workes and word,
Wherefore in the Prophets he is cal
led a strong and unmoveable Rocke,
a castle, a wall, a tower, an inuincible
fortresse, a trealure, & a wel that never
will be drawen drie. This everlasting
GOD can do all thinges, knoweth all
thinges, is present in all places, loveth
mankind exceedingly, doth provide for
al men, and also governeth or disposeth
al things. Faith therefore, which is a
confidence of Gods good will and of his
aide in al necessities, & of the true sal
vation of mantinde, bendeth on god a
lone, & cannot leane to any other crea
ture, in whom the things are not that
faith requireth,
And even as God is true of word, &
can not lye, so is his word true and de
ceiveth no man. In the worde of
God is expressed the will and minde
of God: To the word of God therefore
hath faith an eye, & layeth her ground
uppon Gods worde, touching which
worde the Lorde in the Gospell sayde:
Heaven and earth shall passe, but my
worde shall not passe. The worde of
God here is compared with the most
excellent elementes. Ayre and Wa
ter are feeble and unstable Clements:
but Heaven, although it turne and
mone, doth keepe yet awonderfull and
most stedfast course in mouing, and
stedfast are all thinges therein. The
Earth is most stable and unmovea
ble. Therefore it it be easier for these
thinges to be loased, which cannot be
undone, than for the worde of God to
passe: it followeth that Gods word in
al pointes is most stable, unmonea
ble, and not possible to be loased. I
saith the Lorde in Jeremie) yee can
undoe the leagve that I have taken
with the day, or the covenant that l
have made with the night, so that it
neyther be day nor night at the ap
pointed time, then may my covenant
be of nene effect which I have made
with Daind. But not the whole
worlde laying all their strengthes to
gether, is able to make it day when it
is once night, nor cause the day to
breake one houre sooner than the course
of heaven doth commaunde. There
fore not all this worlde with all the
polver and pompe thereof, shall be able
once to weaken or breake, to chaunge
or abolish so much as one tittle in the
worde of God, and the trueth of gods
worde. Faith therefore, which re
steth upon a thing most firme or sure,
cannot choose but bee an undoubted
certification. And since Gods worde
is the foundation of Faith, Faith can
not wander to and fro, and leane to e
verie worde whatsoever. For every o
pinion conceived without the worde
of God, or against Gods worde, cannot
be called true faith. And for that cause
S. Paule the Apostle of Christ would
not ground the true or Christian faith
uppon any carnall proppes or opinions
of men, but upon the truth and polver
of God. With his wordes will I con
clude this place. Faith (saith he) com
meth of hearing, and hearing by the
worde of God. By the worde of God,
he saith, and not by the word of man,
Againe to the Corinthians: Ay
preaching (sayth he) was not in enti
sing wordes of mans wisedome, but in
the shewing foorth of the spirite, and
of polver, that your faith shoulde not
be in the wisedome of man, but in the
polver of God. Thereby also wee
learne, that some there are, which a
gainst all reason require faith at our
handes, that is, they would have us to
believe that, which they are not able
to shewe out of Gods worde, or that
which is cleane contrarie to the word
of GOD. To the better declaring of
this that I have saide, avayleth that
short abridgement of Gods worde and
of faith, which we in the definition of
faith have closely knit up together
Ther are there rehearsed two chiefe
pointes of faith and of the worde. And
first of all that God in Christ doth free
ly promise life and every good thing.
For God, who is the obiect or marke
and foundation of faith, being of his
owne proper nature everliving ever
lasting, & good, doth of himself from be
ifore all beginning, beget the son like to
himselfe in al points, who because he is
of the same substance with the father,
is himselfe also by nature life and all
goodnesse. And to the ende he might
communicate to us, his Sonnes and
brethren, both life and all goodnesse, he
became man, and being conversant be
rie God and man among men, he testi

whom hee quickneth and silleth with
all goodnesse, and last of all doth take
them uppe to himelfe into the bles
sed place of everlasting life. And that
hee doth frankly and freely bestow this
benefite, to the ende that the glorie of
his grace may in all thinges be pray
sed. This doth true faith believe, and
hereunto belong no small parte of the
Scriptures, which testifie that God in
Christ doth communicate to the faith,
full, life and godlines. John the Apo

And the worde becam flesh, et dwelt

That there is one onely true Faith, and what
the vertue thereof is.
Eing cut off with the
shortnesse of time, & de
teined by the excellencie
of the matter, I coulde
Inot in my last Sermon
make an end of al that I had determi
ned to speake touching faith now ther
fore, by the grace of the holy spirite, I
will adde the rest of the argument
which seemeth yet to be behinde. Pray
to the Lorde, that that which by mans
voice is brought to our eares, may by ye
finger of God be writte in our hearts,
True faith is ignoraunt of all divi
sion, for there is, saith the Apostle, one
Lorde, one Faith, one Baptisme, God
& Father of all. For, there remayneth
from the beginning of the world even
unto the end thereof, one and the same
faith in al the elect of God. God is one
& the same for ever, the only Wel of al
goodnesse, that can never bee drawne
dry. The trueth of God, fro the begin
ning of the world, is one & the same, set
forth to me in the word of God. Ther
fore the obiect and foundation of faith,
that is God & the word of God, remain
for ever one and the selfe same.
In one and the self same faith with
us have all the elect ever since the first
creation of the world beleeved, that un
to us through Christ al good things are
freely given, and that all trueth neces
sarie to bee beleeved is declared in the
word of the Lord: wherefore, the faith,
ful of ye old worlde, have alwaies setled
their faith on God and his worde : so
that now without all doubt, there can
not be any more than one true faith,
I know very well, that in the world
there are sowed manie and sundrye
faithes, that is to say, religions. For
there is the Indian faith, the Jewish
faith, the faith of the Mahometistes, &
the faith of the Gregorias, and yet not
withstading there is but one true chri
stian faith, the abridgement whereof
is contained in the articles of our be
leefe, and is taught at the ful in the sa
cred Scriptures of both the Testa
ments. I know also that there are sun
dry beleefes of men, resting upon sun
dry thinges, and beleeving that which
is contrarie to true faith: but yet ne
verthelesse there remaineth but one
true beleefe in God & his word, (which
is) an undoubted persuasion and confi
dence of things most true, and allured
ly certeine.
This confidence doth growe with
increase in the mindes of hte faithtul, &
contrarily decreaseth againe and ut
terly faileth. And for that cause the A
postles besought the Lord saying: Lord
increase our saith. And Paul the Apo
stle doth in his writinges every where
wish to the faithful the increase of the
spirit & faith. David also, before him
prayed, saying: G God create a cleane
heart within mee, and take not thy
holy spirite from mee. For hee had
seene how that from saul, whome hee
succeeded in the kingdome, the good spi
rite of God was departed, and that in
steade therof the wicked spirit had en
tred into his minde which tormented
him verie pitifully. Hereunto belon
geth that faying in the gospel, To eve
rie one that hath shalbe given, and
from him that hath not shalbe taken
away that which he hath not, or that
he maketh no account of, and shalbee
given to him that hath. Neither was
it in vain, that the Lord said to Peter,
I have prayed for thee Peter, that
thy faith taile not. For Paul spea
keth of some in his time that made
shipwracke of their owne faith, and
overthrew the faith of other. And to
what ende I pray you, doe wee daily
heare the word of God, and make our
humble petitions to the Lorde, but be
cause we looke for increase of godlines,
& his aide to keepe us that we fall not
from true faith: Verily Paul to the
Thessalonians, saith:r wee pray ear
nestly day and night to see yousper
sonally, and to supply that which is
wanting in your taith. And a little
before, he said: For this cause I sent F
motheus, that I might be certified of
your faith, least by any meanes the
tempter had tempted you, and so our
Jabour had beene of no effect. The
same Apostle also in his Epistle to the
Ephesians saith: Christ gave some
Apostles, some Prophets, some Pa
stours ft teachers to the restoring of
the saintes unto the building of the
body of Christ, untill we all meete to
gether in the unitie of faith, and the
acknowledging of the sonne of God,
unto a perfect man, unto the measure
of age of the fulnesse of Christ, so that
now we be no longer children: Ther
fore so long as we live, we learne that
our faith may not be perfect, & if so be
at any time it shall bee weakened by
temptations, that then it may bee re
paired, and againe confirmed. And
in this diversitie(I meane) in this in
crease and weakenesse of faith, there
is no partition or division, for the felfe
roote and substance of faith doeth al
wayes remaine, although it bee at
some time more, & at sometime lesse,
In like manner, faith is not therefore
changed or cut in sunder, because one
is called generall faith, and another
particular faith. For generall faith is
no other than that, which believeth
that al the words of God are true, and
that God hath a good will to mankind.
Particular faith believeth nothing
contrarie to this, onely that which is
common to all, the faithfull applyeth
particularly to himself, helieving that
God is not well minded towarde o
thers alone, but even unto him also.
So then, it bringeth the whole into
partes, and that which is generall in
to particularities. For whereas by
generall faith he believeth that all the
wordes of God are true: in the same
fort by particular faith he doth believe
that the foule is immortall, that our
bodies rise againe, that the faithfull
shalbe saved, the unbelivers destroied,
and whatsoever else is of this forte,
taught to bee believed in the worde of
God. Moreover, the disputation tou
ching faith powvred into us, and faitl
that we our selves get, touching for
mall faith, and faith without fashion,
I believe to bee beaten out of them
which of them selves doe bring these
new disputations into the Church.
True faith is obteined by no stregth
or merite of man, but is poured ints
him of God, as I declared in my last
Sermon: and though man obtaine it
by harkning unto the word of God, yet
neverthelesse, it is wholy imputed to
ye grace of god. For unlesse this grace
do worke in wardly in the heart of the
hearer, ye preacher that laboureth outs
wardly doth bring no profit at all. We
reade in the third chapter of S. Augu
stines booke, De preedestinatione Sanfto
rum. That once he was in an error be
cause hee thought that that faith,
wherewith wee believe in God, is not
the gift of God, but that it was in us as
of out selves, et that by it wee doe ob
tein the gifts of God, wherby we may
in this worlde live rightly ad holilie.
But this he confuteth in that booke at
large & that substantially. So then,
true faith which bedeth on God alone
and is directed by the worde of God, is
formal enough or susficiently in fashis,
Verily the forme of faith is ingraven
in the heart ofthe faithtull, by the holy
Ghost. And although it bee small and
doth not grow up to the highest degree,
yet notwithstanding, it is true fayth
having force in it as it were a grayne
of mustardseede.
The theefe that was crucified with
our Lorde, beleeved in the Lord Jesus,
and was saved, although the force of
faith was strong in him but a verye
small season, and brought not forth a
ny great store of fruite of good workes:
finally, that faith of the theefe was not
any whit divers or contrarie from the
faith of saint Peter and sint Paul,
but was altogether ye very same with
theirs, although their faith brought
forth somwhat more aboundantly the
fruite of good workes. Peter and Paul
were frankly and freely justified, al
though they had manye good workes:
freely was the theef justified, although
his good works were very few or none
at all. Let us hold therefore, that true
faith is one alone, which notwithstan
ding doth increase & is augmented, and
again, may decrease & be ertinguished.
There remaineth now for mee to de
clare, the vertue & effect of true faith,
This hath the holy Apostle Paul done
very excellently well, yea and that
most absolutely too. But although in
the eleventh chapter to the Hebrewes
he had saide very much, he is conspel
led notwithstanding to confesse that he
cannot reckon up all: therefore at this
time I meane to rehearse a fewe ver
tues of faith, leaving the rest (deerely
beloved) to bee sought out & confidered
of your selves.
True faith before al thinges bring
eth with it true knowledge and ma
keth us wise indeede. For by faith wee
knowe God, and judge aright of the
judgementes and woorkes of God, of
vertues and vices. The wisedome that
it bringeth with it, is without doubt ye
true wisedome. Many men hope that
they can attaine to true wisedome by
the ftudie of Philosophie: but they are
deceived as farre as heaven is broade.
For Philosophie doth falsly judge, and
faultily teach many thinges touching
God, the workes of GOD, the chiefe
goodnesse, the ende of good and evil, and
touthing thinges to bee desired and es
chewed. But the verie same thinges
are rightly and truely taught in the
word of God, and understoode and per
ceived by faith. Faith therefore is the
true wisedome, and maketh us wise in
deede. For Jereme also saith. Beholde
they have cast away the worde of the
Lorde, what wisedome therefore can
there be left in them? The wisedome
of salomon, is worshipfully thought
of throughout the whole compasse of
the world. And yet we reade that the
Lord in the Gospell after S. Math, ut
tered this sentence against the Jewes.
The Egeene of the South shall rise in
judgement with this generation and
shall condemne it, because shee came
from the endes of the worlde to heare
the wisedome of salomon: et beholde
there is one in this place greater than
Salomon. Christ is preferred before
Salomon, and the wisedome of Christ
before the wisedome of salomon. But
it is well knowne that the wisedom of
Christ the sonne of God can not bee at
teyned too without faith. Faith there
fore bringeth with it the most ercellet
wisedom. But herein, this wisedom of
ours deserueth a singular prayse, be
cause they that desire it are not sent to
forreine nations, with great cost & la
bour to learne it, as to the priest of
Egypt, the Gymnosophistes of lndia,
the Philosophers of Ereece, or to the
Babines of the lewes. God hath dis
persed the worde of God throughout
the whole world, so that now the word
of faith is in the hearts of all the faith,
full. For Paule the Apostle saith. Thus
saith the justice that is of faith, saye
not in thy heart who shal descend into
heavenr that is, to fetch Christ downe
from above. Or who shall descend in
to the deepe) that is to bring Christ
from the dead againe. But what saith,
he) The worde is nigh unto thee even
in thy heart: this same is the worde of
faith which we preach, for if thou co
fesse with thy mouth the Lord lesus,
and doest beleeve with thy heart that
God hath raised him from the dead
thou shalt be saved. Faith therefore
doth not onely make us wise but hap
pie also, the Lord himself bearing wit
nes thereunto & saying to his disciples.
Nappie are the eyes that see the things
that ye see. For l say unto you that ma
nie prophetes and kinges have desired
to see the things that ye seeret to heare
the thinges that ye heare, et heard the
not. We shall therfore finde in faith, a
most certaine determination of ye most
notalbequestion stirred in, since the be
ginning of the world, of learned & most
excellent wits, which is: by what mea
nes a man may live, be happy, attaine
to the chiefe goodnes, be ioyned to the
chiefe goodnes, & so be justified: There
have been, yea & yet are, divers opinios
touthing this matter, cotrarie the one
to the other. But we do briefely & truly
affirme, that by true faith a man doth
live, is happy, attaineth to ye chief good
nes, is conioyned to the chief goodnes, &
also justified: so ye god dwelleth in us, &
we in him, & that by faith we are both
happy and blessed. What I pray you
could have beene spoke more excellently
worthily or divinely, touching true
faith: for se, faith quikneth us, maketh
us happy, ioineth us to the chiefe good
nes, so ye he in us & we in him may live,
& faith doth also fully justifie us. But
now it is best to heare the testimonies
out of the scriptures. Faith maketh us
happy. For to S. Pet, confessing ye lord
Jesus by true faith it is sayde. Bappie
art thou simon the son of Jonas. Vlesh
and bloud hath not revealed this to
thee, but my father which is in heave.
S. Paul for the proofe of faith bringeth
in that sentence of David. Happi are
they whose iniduities are forgiven and
whose sinnes are covered. Plessed is
the man to who the Lord shall impute
no sinne. Faith dquickneth or maketh a
live. For the just liveth by faith. This
doth Paule very often in his writings
alledge out of the prophets. The same
Paul also saith: The life which nowI
live in flesh, I live by faith in the sonne
of God, who lovedmee and gave him
selfe for me. Faith ioineth us to ye eter
nall & chiefe goodnes, & so maketh us to
inioy ye chief goodnes, ye god may dwell
in us & we in God. For the Lord Jesus
himselfe in the gospell saith. He which
eateth my flesh, &t drinketh my bloud
dwelleth in me, et I in him. As the ly
ving father sent me, so also l live by the
father, et he that eateth me shal live by
me. But to eate & drinkye Lord is to be
lieve in ye Lord, ye he hath given himself
to death for us. Wherupon Johnye A
postle saith. we have seene et do wit
nesse, that the father hath sent the son
the saviour of the worlde. whosoever
shall confesse that lesus is the sonne of
God, God dwelleth in him and he in
God. Wherefore also Paul said: I live
now, not l, but Christ liveth in me,
Moreover faith doth justifie,

no
ende of this houre, I meane to deferre

At this present (dearely beloeved) yee
must rememder, that there is but one
true faith that is the Christian faith,
For although there be said to be many
faithes, that is religions, yet notwith
standing there is onely but one true
and undoubted faith. And that doth
increase and againe decrease in some
men. As for those in whom it is right
ly and godly obserued, in them it shew

bringeth with it true wisedome, final
ly, it quickneth and maketh us blessed
and happy in deede. To God the father
the author of all goodnesse, and of our
felicitie, be al praise and glorie through

ver. Amen

And first of all, I will speake cer
taine things chiefely necessarie to this
argument or treatise, touching this
terme of justification. The terme of
justifying, very usuall and common a
mong the Hebrews, and of a large sig
nification, is not at this day so wel un
quite from judgement, and from the
denounced and uttered sentence of
condemnation. It signifieth to remit
derstoode of all men, as it ought to be,
To justifie, is as much to saye as to
offences, to cleanse, to sanctifie, and to
give utterance of life everlasting. For
it is a lawe terme belonging to courts
where judgement is exercised. Ima
gine therefore, that man is set before
the judgement seate of God, and that
there he is pleaded guiltie, to wit, that
he is accused and conuinced of heinous
offences, and therefore sued to punish
ment or to the sentence of condemna
tion. Imagine also that the son of God
maketh intercession, and commeth in
as a meane, desiring that uppon him
may be layde the whole fault and pu
nishment due unto us men, that he by
his death may cleanse them and take
them away, setting us free from death
and giving us life everlasting. Ima
gine too, that God the most high and
just judge, receiveth the offer, & tran
slateth the punishment together with
the fault from us unto the necke of his
sonne, making therewiehall a statute
that whosoever beleeveth that ye sonne
of God suffered for the sinnes of the
worlde, brake the polver of death, and
delivered us from damnation, shoulde
be cleansed from his sinnes, and made
heire of life everlasting. Who there
fore can be so dul of understanding, but
may perceive that mankind is iustify
ed by faithe
